title: Hamilton Wins In Russia As Rosberg Drops Out
text:
Hamilton Wins In Russia As Rosberg Drops Out 13:48,   Share by email Lewis Hamilton has moved potentially just one race away from a coveted third world championship after winning the Russian Grand Prix while Nico Rosberg retired. 
Another victory in Austin in two weeks' time may now be enough for Hamilton after Rosberg's already-fading challenge was all-but ended by a broken throttle pedal in his Mercedes which forced him to pull out of the Sochi race inside 10 laps. 
Unlike in Japan, Rosberg had managed to fend off Hamilton's advantages at the start to convert his pole position into the lead of the race. 
However, a sticking throttle pedal soon developed in the cockpit of his W06 and after running wide to gift Hamilton the lead, Rosberg was soon heading for the pits and retirement. 
Second place for Sebastian Vettel means it is now the Ferrari driver who is Hamilton's closest title challenger, 66 points behind, but the mathematics are now simple: If Hamilton wins the next race and Vettel finishes no better than third then the Mercedes driver becomes a three-time world champion. 
Rosberg is now 73 points off the pace with just 100 left to play for over the final four races. 
While Rosberg's early demise in Sochi cleared Hamilton's path to a comfortable ninth win of his dominant season and 42nd of his career, the battle for the remaining podium positions was rather more riveting - and unpredictable - as Force India's Sergio Perez. 
While Vettel, having fallen behind team-mate Kimi Raikkonen at the start, worked his way up to second, the battle for third went all the way down to the final lap as the second Ferrari and Valtteri Bottas fast caught Force India's Sergio Perez, who had made an early pitstop under the Safety Car for a huge crash for Romain Grosjean. 
Lotus's Grosjean walked away unharmed from the lap 12 crash despite the impact which left his car in pieces. 
Struggling for grip late on, Perez was overtaken on the penultimate lap by both faster cars, but then was spectacularly gifted back the final podium slot just several corners later when Raikkonen slammed into the side of Bottas's Williams with an opportunistic and seemingly ill-advised lunge. 
Felipe Massa finished fourth from 15th, with Raikkonen fifth but under investigation for the Bottas clash. Promoted Stories
